text.text: Which of the following lines is parallel to \( y = 3x - 4 \)?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall slopes of parallel lines
Two lines are parallel if they have the same slope.
Step 2: Compare the slopes
The line \( y = 3x -4 \) is in slope-intercept form and has slope \( m = 3\). The response \( y=3x+1 \) also has slope \( m = 3\).

text.text: There are two parallel lines. One line has slope \( m_1 \) and the other has slope \( m_2 \). What do we know about the relationship between \( m_1 \) and \( m_2 \)?
Which of the following lines is parallel to \( y = 5 - x \)?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall slopes of parallel lines
Two lines are parallel if they have the same slope.
Step 2: Compare the slopes
The line \( y = 5-x = -x + 5 \) is in slope-intercept form and has slope \( m = -1\). The response \( y-2=-x \) also has slope \( m = -1\).

text.text: Which of the following lines is parallel to \( y - 1 = 3(x +1) \)?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall slopes of parallel lines
Two lines are parallel if they have the same slope.
Step 2: Compare the slopes
The line \( y -1 = 3(x+1) \) is in point-slope form and has slope \( m = 3\). The response \( y=3x+1 \) also has slope \( m = 3\).

text.text: There are two parallel lines. One line has slope \( m_1 \) and the other has slope \( m_2 \). What do we know about the relationship between \( m_1 \) and \( m_2 \)?
Which of the following lines is perpendicular to \( y - 1 = \frac{1}{2}x + 4 \)?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall slopes of perpendicular lines
Two lines are perpendicular if they have slopes whose product is \( -1 \). That is, \( m_1 m_2 = -1 \). With \( m_1 = \frac{1}{2} \) we are looking for a line with slope \( m_2 = \frac{-1}{m_1} = -\frac{1}{\frac{1}{2}} = - 2 \).
Step 2: Check the slopes of each pair of lines
\( y = -2x + 4 \) has slope \( m = -2 \), so it is perpendicular to \( y - 1 = \frac{1}{2}x + 4 \)

text.text: Which of the following pairs of lines are perpendicular to each other?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall slopes of perpendicular lines
Two lines are perpendicular if they have slopes whose product is \( -1 \). That is, \( m_1 m_2 = -1 \).
Step 2: Check the slopes of each pair of lines
\( y - 1 = 2x \) and \( y = -4x  \): \( 2(-4) = -8 \neq -1 \) ✘
\( y = \frac{1}{2}(x-2) \) and \( y = 2x + 5 \): \( \frac{1}{2}(2) = 1 \neq -1 \) ✘
\( y + 1 = 3x \) and \( y = 3x - 1 \): \( 3(3) = 9 \neq -1 \) ✘
\( y - 1 = 2(x-4) \) and \( y = -\frac{1}{2}x + 7 \): \( 2(-\frac{1}{2}) = -1 \) ✔

text.text: There are two lines. One line has slope \( m_1 \) and the other has slope \( m_2 \). What must the relationship be between \( m_1 \) and \( m_2 \) for the two lines to be perpendicular?
Which of the following pairs of lines are perpendicular to each other?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall slopes of perpendicular lines
Two lines are perpendicular if they have slopes whose product is \( -1 \). That is, \( m_1 m_2 = -1 \).
Step 2: Check the slopes of each pair of lines
\( y - 3 = 4(x-5) \) and \( y = -4x + 6 \): \( 4(-4) = -16 \neq -1 \) ✘
\( y + 1 = \frac{1}{2}(x-5) \) and \( y = 2x + 6 \): \( \frac{1}{2}(2) = 1 \neq -1 \) ✘
\( y + 1 = 3x \) and \( y = 3x - 1 \): \( 3(3) = 9 \neq -1 \) ✘
\( y - 3 = 4(x-5) \) and \( y = -\frac{1}{4}x + 6 \): \( 4(-\frac{1}{4}) = -1 \) ✔

text.text: Find the equation of a line that passes through \( (0, 0) \) and \( (5, 5) \) and write it in point-slope form.

feedback.text:
Step 1: Calculate the slope
\( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} = \frac{5-0}{5-0} = \frac{5}{5} = 1 \)
Step 2: Recall slope intercept form
\( y - y_1 = m ( x- x_1) \)
Step 3: Substitute
\( y = x \)

text.text: A line passes through the point \( (x_1, y_1) \) and has slope \( m \). What is the point-slope form of the line?
A line passes through the point \( (x_1, y_1) \) and has slope \( m \). What is the point-slope form of the line?
Find the equation of a line that passes through \( (2, 0) \) and \( (6, -4) \) and write it in point-slope form.

feedback.text:
Step 1: Calculate the slope
\( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} = \frac{-4-0}{6-2} = \frac{-4}{4} = -1 \)
Step 2: Recall slope intercept form
\( y - y_1 = m ( x- x_1) \)
Step 3: Substitute
\( y - 0 = -1 ( x- 2) \)
\( y = -1(x-2) \) which is equivalent to \( y = -(x-2) \)

text.text: Determine the slope of the line that passes through (-9, -4.5) and (-7, -0.5).
Find the equation of a line that passes through \( (2, 1) \) and \( (1, -5) \) and write it in point-slope form.

feedback.text:
Step 1: Calculate the slope
\( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} = \frac{-5-1}{1-2} = \frac{-6}{-1} = 6 \)
Step 2: Recall slope intercept form
\( y - y_1 = m ( x- x_1) \)
Step 3: Substitute
\( y +5 = 6 ( x- 1) \)

text.text: Which of the following correspondences is NOT a function?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the criteria for a function
A correspondence is a function if each value in the domain corresponds to no more than one value in the range.
Step 2: Check to see if correspondence meets criteria
The correspondence \( {(1,3), (1, 5), (1, 7), (1, 9)} \) is NOT a function because the value of \( 1\), a member of the domain, is paired with four different values in the range.

text.text:
Is the following statement about functions True or False?

Multiple values in the domain can correspond to the same value in the range.
Which of the following correspondences is NOT a function?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the criteria for a function
A correspondence is a function if each value in the domain corresponds to no more than one value in the range.
Step 2: Check to see if correspondence meets criteria
The correspondence \( {(32F, snow), (37F, rain), (37F, sleet), (50F, rain)} \) is NOT a function because the value of \( 37F \), a member of the domain, is paired with two different values in the range.

text.text:
Is the following statement about functions True or False?

Multiple values in the domain can correspond to the same value in the range.
Which of the following correspondences is a function?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the criteria for a function
A correspondence is a function if each value in the domain corresponds to no more than one value in the range.
Step 2: Check to see if correspondence meets criteria
For the correspondence \( {(-1,-2), (0, -1), (1, 1), (2, 3)} \),
the domain is the set of first coordinates: {-1, 0, 1, 2}, and
the range is the set of second coordinates: {-2, -1, 1, 3}.

We see that each value in the domain is only paired with one member of the range.

text.text:
Is the following statement about functions True or False?

A value in the domain can correspond to more than one value in the range.
Find the domain of \( f(x) = \frac {x-2}{x^2-3x} \).

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the definition of domain
The domain of a function is the set of all real numbers that when input into the function results in a real number output. Any value that would result in the function being undefined or equal to a non-real number cannot be included in the domain.
Step 2: Consider values that should be excluded from the domain
For \( f(x) = \frac {x-2}{x^2-3x} \), any value of \( x\) that will result in the denominator equalling zero will be excluded from the domain.Setting the denominator equal to zero will help us determine the excluded values.
\( x^2-3x = 0 \)
\( x(x-3) = 0 \)
We see if \( x = 0, 3\), the denominator will equal zero and the function will be undefined. So, the domain of the function is \( x \neq 0, 3 \).

text.text: Find the domain of \( f(x) = \sqrt {x-1} \).

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the definition of domain
The domain of a function is the set of all real numbers that when input into the function results in a real number output. Any value that would result in the function being undefined or equal to a non-real number cannot be included in the domain.
Step 2: Consider values that should be excluded from the domain
For \( f(x) = \sqrt {x-1} \), if the quantity under the square root symbol is negative, the output of the function would be a non-real number.
To prevent this, \( x \geq 1\).

text.text: Values in the domain must never result in function values that are ...
Find the domain of \( f(x) = \frac {x^2-4}{x+3} \).

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the definition of domain
The domain of a function is the set of all real numbers that when input into the function results in a real number output. Any value that would result in the function being undefined or equal to a non-real number cannot be included in the domain.
Step 2: Consider values that should be excluded from the domain
For \( f(x) = \frac {x^2-4}{x+3} \), if the denominator were to equal zero, the function would be undefined. So, the domain of the function cannot include \( x=-3\).
Step 3: Express domain in interval notation
Written in interval notation, the domain of the function would written as \( (-\infty, -3) \cup (-3, \infty) \).

text.text: Which of the following statement most accurately describes the domain of a function?

choices.text: All input values that make the function equal to zero.
choices.name: Choice 2

choices.text: All possible output values for which the function is defined as a real number.
choices.name: Choice 1

choices.text: All possible input values for which the function is defined as a real number.
choices.name: Choice 0

text.text: What is the center and radius of the circle given by \( (x+7)^2 + (y-8)^2 = 25 \)?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the general form of a circle
\( (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2 \) where the center is at \( (h,k) \) and the radius is \( r \)
Step 2: Compare the given equation to the general form
Substituting \( h = -7\), \( k = 8 \), and \( r = 5 \) into the general form reproduces the equation \( (x+7)^2 + (y-8)^2 = 25 \)
Step 3: Final answer
Center: \( (-7, 8) \); Radius: \( r = 5 \)

text.text: What is the center and radius of the circle given by \( (x-2)^2 + (y+9)^2 = 9 \)?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the general form of a circle
\( (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2 \) where the center is at \( (h,k) \) and the radius is \( r \)
Step 2: Compare the given equation to the general form
Substituting \( h = 2\), \( k = -9 \), and \( r = 3 \) into the general form reproduces the equation \( (x-2)^2 + (y+9)^2 = 9 \)
Step 3: Final answer
Center: \( (2, -9) \); Radius: \( r = 3 \)

text.text: Which of the following is the standard form for the equation of a circle?

feedback.text: The general form of a circle is \( (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2 \), where the center is at \( (h,k) \) and the radius is \( r \).

text.text: Consider the circle given by the equation \( (x+4)^2 + (y-4)^2 = 4 \). What is the location of the center of the circle? What is the circle's radius?

feedback.text:
Step 1: Recall the general form of a circle
\( (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2 \) where the center is at \( (h,k) \) and the radius is \( r \)
Step 2: Compare the given equation to the general form
Substituting \( h = -4\), \( k = 4 \), and \( r = 2 \) into the general form reproduces the equation \( (x+4)^2 + (y-4)^2 = 4 \)
Step 3: Final answer
Center: \( (-4,4) \); Radius: \( r = 2 \)

text.text: Which of the following is the standard form for the equation of a circle?

feedback.text: The general form of a circle is \( (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2 \), where the center is at \( (h,k) \) and the radius is \( r \).

text.text: Which of the following is the standard form for the equation of a circle?

feedback.text: The general form of a circle is \( (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2 \), where the center is at \( (h,k) \) and the radius is \( r \).

text.text:
Find the distance between the two points:

\((-2,-3)\) \((4, -7)\)

Find the distance between the two points:

\((6, 3) \) \((4, 2)\)

Find the distance between the two points:

\((1, 2)\) \((-5, -5)\)

Find the midpoint of the segment that has the endpoints: 

(0, 1) (12, 2)

Find the midpoint of the segment that has the endpoints: 

(4, 0) (3, 7)

Find the midpoint of the segment that has the endpoints: 

(6, 3) (4, 2)
What is the symmetry (if any) of the following graph?

feedback.text: The graph is the same when rotated 180 degrees around the origin, therefore it has origin symmetry.

text.text: What is the symmetry (if any) of the following graph?

feedback.text: The graph is reflected across the \( y\)-axis, so it has \( y\)-axis symmetry.

text.text: What is the symmetry (if any) of the following graph?

feedback.text: The graph is the same when it is rotated about the origin by 180 degrees; therefore it has origin symmetry.

text.text: How can the graph of \( f(x) = \frac{1}{2}(x+3)^2 - 8\) be obtained from the graph of \( y = x^2 \)?

choices.text: Shift it horizontally 3 units to the left. Shrink it vertically by a factor of 2. Shift it 8 units down.

text.text:
Sketch the graph of 

\( g(x) =\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} (x+2)^2, & x \leq 0 \\ x-4, & x > 0 \end{array} \right. \)

Sketch the graph of 

\( f(x) =\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 3x+2, & -3 \leq x \leq -1 \\ -2-x, & -1 < x \leq 2 \\ 4x -12, & 2 < x < 4 \end{array} \right. \)

Sketch the graph of 

\( g(x) =\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} -x, & -4 < x < -1 \\ 1, & -1 \leq x < 1 \\ -2x, & x > 1 \end{array} \right. \)

Let \( f(x) =\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 6x^2-4, & x \leq -1 \\ 1+x, & 0 < x \leq 2 \\ 3, & x > 2 \end{array} \right. \)

What is \( f(-2) \)?

Let \( f(x) =\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 2x^2-3x, & x \leq -2 \\ 1+x, & -2 < x < 1 \\ x^2, & x>1 \end{array} \right. \)

What is \( f(0) \)?

Let \( f(x) =\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 2, & x \leq -1 \\ 1-x, & -1 < x \leq 1 \\ 0, & x > 1 \end{array} \right. \)

What is \( f(1) \)?
Let \( f(x) = \frac{x+2}{x-1} \) and \( g(x) = x+1  \). What are \( (f \circ g)(x) \) and \( (g \circ f)(x) \)?
Let \( f(x) = x^2 \) and \( g(x) = x+1  \). What are \( (f \circ g)(x) \) and \( (g \circ f)(x) \)?
Let \( f(x) = x + 5 \) and \( g(x) = x-5  \). What are \( (f \circ g)(x) \) and \( (g \circ f)(x) \)?
